title: Friday, 14th October, 2016
bodyHTML:

11:10 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 203.35, up 8.25 (+4.23%), High: 203.45, Low: 196.75, Volume: 7.77m

Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 3,577, down 20 (-0.56%), High: 3,584, Low: 3,540, Volume: 1.27m
11:11 am
BE

Except the general public, who've been treated pretty shoddily by this story I'd argue.

PM

In what way?

PM

Less Marmite on the streets is a good thing

11:11 am
BE

But it isn't even about Marmite. Marmite's made in Britain.

PM

The gunk gets on your fingers and it's horrible

BE

It's about the several hundred other products Unilever sells, which are imported.

11:12 am
BE

Or which are made to a greater extent from imported ingredients.

BE

Whereas Marmite's a brewery byproduct, isn't it? Leading every story with "Marmite Wars" is somewhere between condescending and downright dishonest.

BE

What we're talking about is food inflation.

11:13 am
BE

Which is quite an important issue.

PM

It is important

PM

But doesnt draw clicks in quite the same way

11:15 am
BE

Populism's fine, but I really think this particular spat -- and Tesco's excellent PR spinning of it, incidentally -- has somewhat buried the big-picture argument.

PM

test

BE

So, as a corrective, here's Morgan Stanley to provide that.

11:16 am
BE

We believe that British grocers will find it more difficult to
pass on input cost inflation derived by Sterling depreciation
this time around. Given higher operational gearing, this implies
further margin pressure

BE

It is increasingly clear that the depreciation of Sterling post the Brexit vote is
driving inflationary pressures upwards. As followers of the UK grocery sector
will be aware, the UK has experienced retail food deflation since summer 2014.
This was mostly a function of conventional grocers' efforts (i.e. the Big 4) to try
narrowing the price gap with the discounters. Given the depreciation of the
Sterling (-20% and -17% vs. the USD and EUR respectively over the past 12
months), potentially higher tariffs and the disruption of the supply chain, it now
looks increasingly likely that this would lead to a material increase in food input
costs for the UK. Indeed, over the past few weeks leading Food and HPC
manufacturers such as Nestle, Danone, SCA or Unilever have also indicated that
they would raise prices in the UK in the short to medium term. As per
government data (ONS), Food PPI turned positive in July 2016 (after being
deflationary since March 2014). In August (lasted available data), Food PPI
increased +1.9% YoY (see Exhibit 1) and on the back of some commodity price
increase (e.g. soybean, coffee or sugar) and Sterling depreciation, looks set to
increase further in the coming months. Assuming that input cost would go up
~£5.5bn over the next 12 months (i.e. ~£110bn up ~5%), it looks highly unlikely
that the retailers can fully absorb this increase, given the industry profit pool has
now fallen to ~£3bn (e.g. Tesco's UK EBIT margin stood at only 1.1% in FY16), so a
good chunk will have to be passed on to consumers; under this scenario, to keep
the profit pool constant in £ terms, they would need to pass on to consumers at
least 75% of the input cost inflation. (For the latest views of Morgan Stanley’s
Economics and FX teams, please read: Heading for a Harder Brexit.) Rising input
prices are largely in line with our expectations and hence we do not make any
changes to forecasts at this time.

BE

However, grocers' ability to pass input cost inflation to consumers is lower than
during the latest major Sterling depreciation, we believe. Back in 2008, Sterling
depreciated by -31% vs the USD in the 12 months to January 2009 and -25% vs.
the Euro in the 12 months to December 2008. The resulting input cost inflation
was almost entirely passed on, as evidence by strong inflation at retail (+9.1% in
2008 and +5.6% in 2009) as well as little margin pressure. However, back then
the Big 4 acted as a de facto oligopoly: combined, they had close to 75% market
share, making the UK the most consolidated European market. And industry
gross margin expanded over the 2005-2015 period a, a function of industry
leader Tesco needing its domestic cashflow in order to fund its international
expansion, as well retailers needing to offset SG&A pressure as a function of the
space race (supply growth significantly outstript demand over the period). As we
discuss below, the industry dynamics have quite dramatically changed since
2008, making it more difficult - in our view - for grocers to fully pass on input
cost inflation.

11:17 am
BE

Should food inflation pick up, this might accelerate channel shift in favour of
the discounters. In the aftermath of the 2008 Financial Crisis, grocers in the UK
were negatively impacted by down trading within the stores. For example,
Sainsbury indicated that in 4Q08, its 'B asics' range sales were up 40% y-o-y, while
sales of its premium 'Taste the Difference' range were down. As per Kantar, down
trading impacted sales by ~300 bps back in 2008 (this was masked then by high
food inflation, as discussed above). There could be a repeat of that situation over
the coming two to three years should consumer spending come under pressure.
However, what has changed since 2008 is that UK households have a much
greater ability to downtrade not just within stores, but by shopping at
discounters. While Aldi and Lidl had only ~850 stores combined when the
financial crisis started in 2008 (and less than 5% market share), they now have
1,350 stores (and a 10% market share - up +140 bps y-o-y). Over the past three
years, the Big 4 have - on aggregate - managed to narrow the price gap with the
discounters. However, this has only be a gradual process and we believe that Aldi
and Lidl still have a material price advantage: we estimate that for products of
equivalent quality, the Big 4 prices are still ~18% higher than that of the
discounters – see Exhibit 2 . Of note, we do not believe that Sterling depreciation
reduces the competitive advantage of discounters, as some have suggested.
Based on discussions with industry contacts, we believe that the UK's largest
discounter, Aldi, sources ~50% locally, a proportion similar to the Big 4 (Lidl
might rely a touch more on sourcing from Continental Europe).

BE

A depreciation of Sterling could also mean a greater willingness from Asda to
reset its prices. As per our estimates, Asda accounted for ~8% and ~7% of
Walmart's consolidated sales and EBIT in the fiscal year ending January 2016.
With Sterling down 20% vs. the USD over the past 12 months, Asda's share of
WMT sales should fall to ~7% (and ~4% of EBIT) in the current fiscal year. As a
result, and given that Walmart's performance in North America has been
improving as of late, we believe that Walmart might be (even) more willing to
reset prices at Asda this year given Asda's significant decline in sales density over
the past two years. Additionally, we note that Asda's EBIT margin stood at 5.5%
in calendar 2015. This compares to 2.7% for Sainsbury, 2.1% for Morrisons and
1.1% for Tesco. Hence, Asda is in a stronger position than its peers to absorb
future price increase, and therefore disrupt the competitive landscape.

BE

Finally, eCommerce penetration has more than doubled in the UK since 2008,
increasing price transparency. Based on Mintel and Kantar data, we estimate that
online penetration, between 2008 and today, has increased from 9.5% to 20% in
non-food and from 2,5% to 6% in food. This makes the UK the country with the
highest online penetration in the world (only South Korea is similar).

11:18 am
PM

that's interesting

BE

Charts as well.

BE

11:19 am
BE

(Reminder to self: I need to unclick the "show mouse pointer" option on ShareX.)

BE

Quick line from David Mccarthy at HSBC as well.

BE

The depreciation of the pound is leading to cost increases for suppliers, but Tesco is resisting. Tesco is well placed to do so, as it is delivering the best volume growth to most of its suppliers. If Tesco is delivering 5% volume growth to a supplier and that supplier has operational gearing of 4 to 1, the supplier's profits are up 20%. It is easy for Tesco to say "take the price increase out of the profits and we will give you more growth next year". It is harder for Tesco's mainstream competitors who are not delivering anywhere near the volume growth and therefore will have much less (if anything) to negotiate with. Tesco is utilising cost inflation as a weapon.

11:21 am
BE

The myth of inflation: That retailers want cost inflation is a wrong and ill-informed myth. It was high inflation in c2008-14 that has caused the industry problems of today and almost all the current CEOs know this and will not repeat the mistake. Increases in the minimum wage are not regarded as good news, so why should the increase in CoGs be regarded as such? Tesco strategy is to keep prices low and to use volume gains and cost cutting to fund price cuts. This will put huge pressure on competitors.

BE

...... which picks up on yesterday's argument, shared here. "wrong and ill informed", apparently.

BE

Competitors are put into a difficult situation. Do they accept the price rise and maintain availability but appear to have given in with higher prices, or do they hold the line with Tesco but then risk embarrassment if Tesco strike a deal. ASDA is particularly exposed as any price repositioning will now have to be dealt with from a higher cost base. In retailing, if there is a problem, it is better to solve it today as it will be more expensive to solve it tomorrow. ASDA's solution is getting more expensive in our view. We remain slightly cautious on Tesco, until we see ASDA move.

11:22 am
BE

But that's enough grocery.

The one I've not seen any recent press on, incidentally, is Sky Bet.

I note this in part because William Hill's in trouble again.

(Or reverse takeover, to be picky.)

BE

11:30 am

11:31 am

hehe

BE

Amaya's a very problematic business that is in many ways opposite to William Hill's strategy, which seems to have been totally abandoned over the past month.

11:32 am
BE

Why? Dunno.

BE

Though I guess when 888 -- !!!! -- tries to buy you, it can focus the mind.

BE

Lots of stuff around this morning suggesting Parvus is putting William Hill in play here.

11:34 am
BE

Liberum, for instance.

BE

(WMH LN) Last night the largest shareholder (14.3%) in William Hill – Parvus - published an open letter in which it comprehensively rejected the potential merger with Amaya as 1. It makes no strategic sense to them (cross-sell into Poker is very difficult), 2. Valuation – Parvus estimate that Hills is paying a c.50% EV/EBITDA premium for Amaya and that Hills’ current ‘fair value’ is c.30% above the current share price 3. The level of leverage is too great to the effect that the deal would leave the Group with £2.8bn of proforma net debt – far higher than the previous bid from 888/Rank which Parvus may have supported.

Against this backdrop it is hard to see how the deal can progress although Hills’ Board are only at early stage of DD discussions with Amaya and will almost certainly want to continue these to see if they could eventually recommend a deal.

What is clear is that Parvus have hung up the ‘For Sale’ sign at Hills and the Company remains ‘in play’.

In our view £100m of synergies with any potential partner pushes the share price towards 400p or beyond if a bid premium materialises.

BE

And Cenkos.

11:34 am
BE

In our view, given the impending review of stakes and prizes which we think, on balance, is likely to lead to a reduction in the maximum stake for B2 gaming machine content (FOBTs), now is not the optimum time to consider such a move but agree that the group's M&A activity has been skittish as the group has found itself increasingly boxed into a corner.

BE

Now, all of this leads me to wonder if there's an obvious solution ....................

PM

Such as?

11:36 am
BE

........ as in, William Hill needs an online business. CVC wants to cash in on Sky Bet. The midmarket for IPOs looks to be in real trouble.

PM

Oh i see

BE

So .... look, it's not a new suggestion that these two businesses would fit together quite well, without all of the issues surrounding unregulated markets and the sinking craphole that is online poker.

11:38 am
BE

(Retrospectively, I'm not sure "sinking craphole" is an appropriate phrase, and apologise for it.)

PM

(The BBC has some list of which profanities are okay at different times of the day -- and I think 'crap' is generally accepted.)

PM

(But it's the way you use it, i guess)

11:39 am
BE

I doubt CVC would buy William Hill. But William Hill might plausibly give CVC an exit. It'd be easier for them to raise £1.5bn for a genuinely transformational acquisition, even if it's probably not exactly what Parvus wants either.

BE

But this is me speculating wildly, to be clear.

undefined
11:40 am
PM

So Citi have one of their huge GPS things out -- on virtual reality

PM

VR and AR

PM

Ive got a copy but don't have a link I'm afraid

11:41 am
PM

I was going to write this up -- but I just find it fantastical

PM

And don't want to be too rude to Citi, since I was supping their champers at the Shanghri Lai the other night

PM

But tell me what you think

11:42 am
PM

Over the next five years, we believe hardware, primarily VR headsets for gaming,
will be the driver of industry growth and we think the overall VR/AR market could
reach $692 billion by 2025 and continue to ramp after that. Although initially the
primary content for VR will be game software, the market will then expand to include
concerts, zoos, and theme parks before broadening further to encompass sports,
movies, TV programs, and music.

PM

In the future, given that AR headsets allow for mobility versus VR headsets, we
believe the pattern of use of AR will resemble that of smartphones and we think AR
will start to erode the smartphone market on both the hardware and software sides.
In our current model, we assume the majority of growth in the AR headset market
will occur from 2025 onward and will be achieved at the expense of the smartphone
market. Consumer behavior with AR devices is likely to be similar to that of
smartphones so we anticipate that consumers will increasingly use their AR
headsets for commerce. Given the global e-commerce and m-commerce market is
currently around $1 trillion, and is expected to rise to $4 trillion by 2030, even if
VR/AR only gets a small percentage of the market, it would be a significant driver to
the growth of the VR/AR market overall. Forecasting out to 2035, we believe AR
could grab about 25% of the m-commerce market which would equate to almost
$1.3 trillion.

PM

There's a 126 pages of that stuff

11:42 am
PM

Which I'm not going to paste here -- but will UP it

PM

Do you buy that Bryce -- that VR/AR head sets will be the new smart phones?

BE

Yes. Disclaimer: I'm long VR.

11:43 am
PM

I keep trying these things -- and Google cardboard

PM

And think, WTF, this is dumb

BE

As have I and that wasn't my response.

11:44 am
PM

I think one of the unintended consequences of QE that we haven't flagged is that lots of people have become gullible

PM

The BBC had some story about a Russian wanting to set up a new state in space

PM

And it gets coverage everywhere

11:45 am
PM

And you think -- this is nonsense

BE

I'm not sure I understand the parallel you're drawing. Are you saying VR's apparent popularity is due to lax reporting standards?

PM

No no

11:46 am
PM

It's just that people are attaching huge importance to things that are clearly fantasy or hyped to the roof tops -- or just fads

PM

Remember that Pokemon GO thing

PM

That added billions and billions to Nintendo's market cap

11:46 am
PM

Cos this was the new new thing that was going to take over

PM

And then it didn't

PM

And everyone forgotten about it already

11:47 am
PM

Cos it was a stupid fad

PM

I think VR might be the same

PM

11:47 am
PM

That's Pokemon Go on google trends

BE

We're tempted to dismiss everything novel as a fad and a flash in the pan. The benefit to Nintendo wasn't really Pokemon Go though. It was the ability to shift perhaps the world's biggest and most valuable collection of character IP onto mobile.

PM

For abou 10 days

11:48 am
BE

Most of the Pokemon Go benefit for Nintendo's stuck, though.

BE

Secondly, I also note the number of installs for Google Cardboard (10m to 50m on Play, approximately the same on Apple Store ....) ..... Which looks pretty good.

BE

One can see this as a fad, sure. The numbers for Pokemon Go are similar I'm sure.

11:49 am
PM

People keep giving me Google cardboard things -- i keep googling for content and every piece i try is just rubbish

BE

But we've seen this model before, with things like the iPod Touch.

BE

You convince people to try something by lowering the cost to try out a reasonably interesting thing.

11:49 am
BE

Quite a few of them like it, and upgrade.

BE

That's what Google Cardboard does, and I'm genuinely convinced it's going to popularise VR.

PM

Well you can have my cardboards then. I will bring em in tomorrow

11:51 am
BE

Because while I'm sure there are plenty of cynical people, there are also plenty -- like me, as it happens -- who are quite impressed by the ability to put a phone into a cardboard thing and wander around an arctic landscape.

PM

These supposedly 3d videos don't even work. They are just surround cameras -- which have been around for 15/20 years

BE

No, they're clearly not. That's just a silly argument.

11:51 am
PM

Actually, no stop -- I experienced this at Disneyland in LA when I was about 8 years old

PM

Which is a long long time ago

BE

Yes, maybe. Anecdotally, it does seem the UK IPO midmarket is moribund. No appetite whatsoever.
